snippet.title: Everyday Ham
snippet.description:
A couple of Michigan Amateurs getting together monthly to discuss current Ham Radio topics in an approachable, conversational format! We'll share our learning and experience of operating the radio, while talking equipment, modes and preparedness as it intersects in the amateur radio hobby.

Hosted by N8JRD - Jim, K8JKU - James, and Rory - W8KNX

snippet.title: Ham Radio Repeater Upgrades - Touring a Vintage Motorola Micor Repeater Site
snippet.description:
Head to the home of the N8SL 2m Repeater to take a tour of the vintage Motorola Micor Repeater that keeps our club connected!    Join the SLAARC Technical Chair W8KNX along with N8LEK and N8JRD as they take care of some maintenance and upgrades that keep this old repeater on the air and connected to ALLSTAR and ECHOLINK.  

Get your ALLSTAR Node here and come chat with us!
https://kits4hams.com/

snippet.title: Kits 4 Hams SHARI Allstar Node & Mortty V5 | Hamcation 2026
snippet.description:
James (K8JKU) talks with Steve (N8AR), creator of the SHARI Allstar Node, at the Kits 4 Hams booth at Hamcation 2026. Steve walks us through his line of SHARI nodes including the newer SHARI PiHat NeoPi5 model designed for the Raspberry Pi 5, discusses his pre-assembled units and kit options, and the support and service he provides. They also cover the Mortty V5, a precision CW and RTTY keying device. Whether you’re looking to build or buy, Steve has you covered.

🔗 Kits 4 Hams: https://www.kits4hams.com
🔗 Mortty: https://www.mortty.net

snippet.title: Icom IC-7300MK2: The Upgrade We’ve Been Waiting For?| Hamcation 2026
snippet.description:
James (K8JKU) and Rory (W8KNX) sit down with Ray Novak (N9JA) from Icom America at Hamcation 2026 to talk about the IC-7300MK2. Ray walks us through the key upgrades over the original IC-7300 including HDMI output for an external display, USB Type-C with dual virtual COM ports, built-in LAN for simplified remote operation, improved receiver performance, and overall better efficiency. If you loved the IC-7300, this is the upgrade you’ve been waiting for.

🔗 Icom America: https://www.icomamerica.com
🔗 IC-7300MK2: https://www.icomamerica.com/lineup/products/IC-7300MK2/

snippet.title: Is the Heil BM-17 Coming Back? Update from Hamcation 2026
snippet.description:
Rory (W8KNX) talks with Jerry (KE9AKK) from Heil Ham Radio at Hamcation 2026 about the popular BM-17 headset and when we can expect it to return. The BM-17 has been a favorite lightweight boom headset for ham radio operators, especially for POTA and emergency communications, and Rory gets a direct update from the rep on its status.

🔗 Heil Ham Radio: https://heilhamradio.com

snippet.title: Seeed Studio Mesh Networking: Meshtastic vs Meshcore | Hamcation 2026
snippet.description: Jim (N8JRD) talks with David (KB5UTY) and Jinger Zeng from Seeed Studio at Hamcation 2026. They explain what Seeed Studio does, walk us through their line of mesh networking products including the L1 “tiny” node available in 4 versions, and break down the advantages of Meshtastic versus Meshcore. Seeed Studio offers solid products at very reasonable prices, making mesh networking accessible for everyone. @SeeedStudioSZ

snippet.title: FlexRadio Aurora AU-510M: 500W SDR Powerhouse | Hamcation 2026
snippet.description:
Jim (N8JRD) talks with Tony (K1KP) from FlexRadio at Hamcation 2026 about the Aurora AU-510M, a 500W integrated SDR transceiver with a built-in Maestro front panel, power supply, and automatic antenna tuner all in one chassis. Covering HF through 6 meters, the AU-510M features SmartSignal adaptive predistortion, MultiFlex dual-operator capability, and SmartLink for remote operation. Priced at $7,349.

🔗 FlexRadio: https://www.flexradio.com
🔗 Aurora AU-510M: https://www.flexradio.com/products/aurora-au-510m-signature-series/

snippet.title: NEW Buddihex Mini & Mastwerks Precision Antenna Rotator | Hamcation 2026
snippet.description:
Rory (W8KNX) sits down with Chris Drummond (W6HFP) and John Nagel (W5EXJ) from Buddipole at Hamcation 2026 to check out the new Buddihex Mini, a 3-band hex beam covering 12, 10, and 6 meters, available for pre-order at $450. They also get a first look at the Mastwerks Precision Antenna Rotator (MWR), a field-ready azimuth rotator designed specifically for the Buddihex and Mastwerks tripod/mast systems, with an introductory price of $285. Plus, a closer look at the full-size Buddihex.

🔗 Buddipole: https://www.buddipole.com
🔗 Mastwerks: https://www.mastwerks.com

snippet.title: Four Hams, One Screen, and Zero Instructions - Upgrading the Club Meeting Space
snippet.description:
The Everyday Ham crew volunteered to help hang a new projector screen at the historic Witch's Hat Depot in South Lyon! Just your friendly neighborhood hams from the South Lyon Area Amateur Radio Club giving back to the community, one questionable measurement at a time. Turns out we're better at hanging antennas, but we got it done! 💪

snippet.title: Do You Really Need a New Radio? Honest Ham Radio Upgrade Advice
snippet.description:
Do you really need that new radio? In Episode 14 of the Everyday Ham Podcast, James (K8JKU), Jim (N8JRD), and Rory (W8KNX) get honest about the pressure to upgrade ham radio equipment — and what they’ve learned from their own buying mistakes.

We start with a moment of remembrance for Elwood Downey, creator of the beloved HamClock, and share what his work meant to the amateur radio community.

📻 What’s in this episode:
0:00 Remembering HamClock creator Elwood Downey
3:40 Around the shack — CW practice updates and the Hamgeek CW Morse Pokemon HamCube Pro trainer review
7:33 James tries hotel radio from Germany with a QRP rig and an end-fed out the window
9:26 Winter Field Day recap and shout-outs
11:07 The big topic — When was the last time you felt pressure to upgrade a radio?
18:41 Why antenna upgrades beat radio upgrades every time
20:47 Jim’s honest $10K shack confession — what he’d do differently
23:43 Taking advantage of band openings with any station
27:37 Embrace the journey — there’s no wrong way to ham
31:08 Hamcation and Hamvention buying season advice
33:29 Rory’s BuddiHEX plans — next great antenna or next regrettable purchase?
44:25 Backpacking gear, adapters, and hamfest bargain hunting
46:33 Hamcation Orlando 2026 preview — come say hello!

🔗 Links & Resources:
Hamgeek CW Morse Pokemon HamCube Pro: https://www.hamgeek.com
Long Island CW Club: https://longislandcwclub.org
BuddiPole / BuddiHEX: https://www.buddipole.com/buddihex2.html

Available on Apple Podcasts, Spotify, Overcast, and more.

🔗 All links: https://www.everydayham.com

snippet.title: Do You Really Need a New Radio? Honest Ham Radio Upgrade Advice
snippet.description:
Send us a text (https://www.buzzsprout.com/twilio/text_messages/2438895/open_sms) 


Do you really need that new radio? In Episode 14, James (K8JKU), Jim (N8JRD), and Rory (W8KNX) get honest about the pressure to upgrade ham radio gear and share what they’ve learned from their own buying mistakes.


We begin with a moment of remembrance for Elwood Downey, creator of HamClock, and share what his contributions meant to the community. Then we catch up around the shack — Jim’s new CW trainer, James’s hotel radio experiments from Germany, and Rory’s progress with Morse code through the Long Island CW Club.


The main topic digs into upgrade pressure. Jim confesses his $10K shack might not outperform his old $890 FT-DX10 and $99 end-fed combo. Rory makes the case that antennas matter more than radios. James shares his FTX-1F disappointment and why he went crawling back to his trusted FT-891. The unanimous takeaway: more antenna, less radio.


We also talk BuddiHEX plans, hamfest buying strategies heading into Hamcation and Hamvention season, and preview our upcoming trip to Orlando.


Don’t miss a single episode! Follow the Everyday Ham Podcast on your favorite podcast platform (Apple Podcasts, Spotify, Overcast, and more) and be sure to subscribe to our YouTube channel.


https://www.everydayham.com

snippet.title: Brutal Cold: Winter Field Day at -17°F - Our 2026 WFD Experience | W8EDH
snippet.description:
What happens when you try to operate ham radio during one of the coldest winter weekends Michigan has seen in years? We found out!

Join James (K8JKU), Jim (N8JRD), and Rory (W8KNX) as we recap our 2026 Winter Field Day experience operating as the Everyday Ham Amateur Radio Club using callsign W8EDH. With temperatures plunging to -17°F (-27°C) and dangerous winter storms sweeping the country, we set up at a cabin in the woods with 8 total operators and logged 845 QSOs across multiple bands.

⏱️ TIMESTAMPS
0:00 - Driving to Winter Field Day in -17°F
0:15 - What is Winter Field Day?
0:42 - Why the Everyday Ham Club decided to participate
1:18 - The brutal Michigan weather conditions
2:03 - Jim's Winter Field Day experience
3:09 - Heating problems at the cabin (51°F inside!)
3:53 - James arrives after the heating crisis
4:18 - First time doing a real contest
4:56 - Our antenna setup strategy
5:54 - The 40m monster vertical antenna
6:06 - Antenna walkthrough (40m vertical, Aerial-51 OCFD, Band Hopper)
7:21 - Results: 845 QSOs and contest stats
7:55 - Using World Radio League logger
8:43 - Stats breakdown (110 QSOs in fastest hour, 28 average)
9:24 - Bands we operated (40m, 20m, 80m, 15m, 10m, 2m, 220, 440)
10:06 - Getting CW contacts with Terry W8TMB
10:36 - Multipliers and bonus objectives
11:01 - Running on alternative power (battery vs generator RFI)
11:28 - Winlink email adventure (and the Nigerian prince joke)
12:30 - More multipliers: six bands, multiple modes, continuous operation
12:54 - Objectives we missed (satellites, WFD bulletin, QRP)
13:12 - Total operators (8) and visitors (16+)
13:30 - The W8EDH club callsign
13:44 - Coaching new operators
14:04 - Join our Discord for event info
14:24 - Looking ahead to Summer Field Day & QSO parties
15:06 - Closing montage: Final contacts and packing up

📻 WHAT WE COVERED
- Setting up a multi-operator station in extreme cold
- Running three radios on battery and generator power
- Tips for first-time contesters using World Radio League
- The importance of resonant antennas for contesting
- How to encourage and coach new operators
- Winlink email bonus objective (and the Nigerian prince joke)

🔗 RESOURCES
Winter Field Day Association: https://winterfieldday.org/
World Radio League: https://www.worldradioleague.com/
South Lyon Area Amateur Radio Club (SLAARC): https://www.slaarc.com/

🎙️ ABOUT EVERYDAY HAM
Three friends diving into amateur radio with a casual, lighthearted twist. From current events and lessons learned to our gripes and off-topic banter, we bring fun, relatable conversations and radio expertise.

📱 FOLLOW US
Website: https://www.everydayham.com/

Don't miss an episode! Subscribe to our YouTube channel and follow Everyday Ham on your favorite podcast platform (Apple Podcasts, Spotify, Overcast, and more).

#WinterFieldDay #WFD2026 #HamRadio #AmateurRadio #W8EDH #Contesting #EmergencyComms #PortableRadio #MichiganHam #EverydayHam

snippet.title: Kenwood TM-D750A FCC Filing Reveals All! First Look at the Specs
snippet.description:
The Kenwood TM-D750A is officially real! The FCC filing has been approved and the user guide has been posted online, revealing key specifications for this highly anticipated tri-band mobile radio. Join James (K8JKU), Jim (N8JRD), and Rory (W8KNX) as we break down everything we learned from the FCC documents.

In this episode, we discuss our price predictions (will it be $999, $1299, or even $1500?), the 7-inch display, 220 MHz power output (20 watts!), Wi-Fi and Bluetooth 5.0 capabilities, GPS, D-STAR features, and why the microphone port placement has us scratching our heads.
Plus, we talk tri-band antenna options and whether Rory will actually buy one at Hamcation!

snippet.title: Learning CW in 2026: Two Paths to Morse Code Success
snippet.description:
Five watts, a tiny coil antenna on a travel tripod, and a camera-bag station that reaches across states—CW isn't a relic, it's a practical advantage. In this episode, we invited Terry W8TMB to walk us through how he learned Morse code without drowning in drills, why CW pairs perfectly with POTA and QRP, and what actually works when your sending is solid but your copy lags behind.

We compare two popular learning paths: CW Academy and Long Island CW Club. CW Academy offers a free, semester-style program with fixed class times and steady accountability—great if you thrive with structure. Long Island CW Club takes a different approach with flexible, year-round carousels, multiple time slots each week, and an emphasis on getting on the air early. Their $30/year (or $90 lifetime) membership includes about 170 classes per week, a powerful browser-based practice tool, and thoughtful accessibility options for autistic, visually impaired, and hearing-impaired hams.

From there we dig into practical tactics: stop counting dits and dahs—train your ear to recognize full characters. Use Farnsworth spacing to create breathing room. Drill random call signs to break predictability. Send back what you copy immediately to lock it in. Ditch the decoders and cheat sheets; they slow your ear. Code-talk license plates on road trips, work short daily sessions, and aim your practice at real exchanges like POTA and simple contests.

Terry's field kit shows what's possible when you combine clean CW signals with smart packing: a five-band QRP rig (the CFT-1), a lightweight 3D-printed coil antenna from Ham Radio Duo, and a 16Wh battery that lasted through two hours of contacts with 75% remaining. As bands shift with the solar cycle, CW keeps you in the game with narrow bandwidth, stronger SNR, and easy-to-carry gear.

snippet.title: You Don't Need HF for POTA — Just a Handheld and Friends
snippet.description:
POTA doesn't have to be complicated. Sometimes it's just grabbing some friends, some handhelds, and seeing what you can do.

If you're a Technician class operator and you've been wanting to get into Parks on the Air but thought you needed HF — you don't. This video shows how four hams activated parks across Michigan's Thumb region using only quad-band handheld radios. No HF. No antennas. No complicated setup.

This method works for:
- Technician class operators who don't have HF privileges
- Operators with limited mobility — no antenna setup, activate from a parking lot or bench
- Restricted parks like nature preserves and wildlife refuges — walk in, make contacts, walk out, leave no trace

It started as an idea in a group chat. We got it out of the chat and into reality.

That's the spirit of Parks on the Air — getting outside with friends, setting ambitious goals, and trying something new.

🔗 Links & Resources:
Parks on the Air: https://parksontheair.com
Wouxun KG-Q10H: https://www.buytwowayradios.com/wouxun-kg-q10h.html
Everyday Ham Podcast: https://www.everydayham.com

🎧 Don't miss an episode! Follow the Everyday Ham Podcast on your favorite podcast platform (Apple Podcasts, Spotify, Overcast, and more) and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

- Website: https://www.everydayham.com

snippet.title: Our First Christmas! 🎄 73 from The Everyday Ham Team
snippet.description:
Merry Christmas and Happy New Year from the entire team at The Everyday Ham!

It’s officially our first Christmas as a podcast, and we couldn't let the year end without hopping on the air to say a massive THANK YOU. 2025 has been an incredible start, and we are so grateful for every listener, subscriber, and contact we've made along the way.

snippet.title: 2026 Ham Radio Predictions: New Rigs, Community & What's Next
snippet.description:
What does 2026 have in store for ham radio? In this episode of Everyday Ham, James (K8JKU), Jim (N8JRD), and Rory (W8KNX) share their bold predictions for the year ahead — covering new rigs, the future of our community, and what's next for the hobby.

We start in the shack with winter POTA prep, a feather-light 33-foot mast, a fiber-fueled network overhaul, and a pair of pristine rotary phones begging for a ham project. Then we dig into the predictions.

On the gear side, we share our predictions for what hardware might be on the horizon — what we'd love to see from the major manufacturers and where we think the industry is heading.

But hardware isn't the whole story. We spend time on community — why POTA and SOTA remain the heartbeat of growth, how repeaters can make a comeback through AllStar links and creative nets, and why "leave no call unanswered" might be the culture shift that keeps VHF/UHF alive and welcoming. College clubs are buzzing again, and the formula scales: be kind, run practical events, and meet people where they are.

We also talk AI in ham radio (helpful, not magical), and wrap with personal goals — Extra class ambitions and a fresh pull toward CW.

snippet.title: 2026 Ham Radio Predictions: New Rigs, Community & What's Next
snippet.description:
Send us a text (https://www.buzzsprout.com/twilio/text_messages/2438895/open_sms) 


What does 2026 have in store for ham radio? A year into the podcast, James (K8JKU), Jim (N8JRD), and Rory (W8KNX) turn up the dial with a forward look at the hobby's near future — grounded in real gear, real operating, and real community.

We start in the shack with winter POTA prep, a feather-light 33-foot mast, a fiber-fueled network overhaul, and a pair of pristine rotary phones begging for a ham project. Then we get into the predictions.

On the gear side, we share our predictions for what hardware might be on the horizon — what we'd love to see from the major manufacturers and where we think the industry is heading.

But hardware isn't the whole story. POTA and SOTA remain the heartbeat of growth because they lower the barrier to entry and make radio feel alive. We share why portable operating will keep rising even as solar conditions tighten.

At home, we're betting on a repeater revival — AllStar links, creative nets like SSTV nights, and "leave no call unanswered" as the culture shift that keeps VHF/UHF useful and welcoming. College clubs are buzzing again, and the formula scales: be kind, run practical events, and meet people where they are — on-air, at meetups, or on Discord.

AI comes up, minus the hype. Think helpful, not magical: audio-assisted logging, smarter noise control, and developer tooling that speeds up ham software. It's another tool, like a good tuner — valuable when it saves time and stays out of the way.

We wrap with personal goals — Extra class ambitions and a fresh pull toward CW — and a reminder that every license class is valid. The hobby thrives when we celebrate each step and keep the airwaves friendly.

Connect with us:
🌐 Website: https://www.everydayham.com
📷 Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/everydayhampodcast/
💬 Discord: Join our community at everydayham.com

snippet.title: SpiderBeam Aerial 51 - The Best Portable Antenna You Haven't Heard About?
snippet.description:
Join Jim N8JRD and James K8JKU head out to the park to do a 3-way Pota Wire antenna comparison and discuss Spiderbeam's Aerial-51 wire antenna.   This off center fed dipole may be one of the most interesting wire antennas you haven't heard about, offering fast access to a broad array of the amateur radio bands without the need for a wideband tuner!    We also compare it to other popular antennas from Packtenna and Sotabeams.   

Which antenna works best, do you need an Aerial 51 in your kit?  Come along and find out on this Everyday Ham MicCheck.

Table of Contents:
00:16 - Intro, 3-Antennas Specifications
04:46 - Aerial 51 Setup and Considerations
06:50 - Making some QSO's on the Aerial 51 on 40m
10:23 - 15m Testing
13:48 - SWR Testing and Comparing to Manufacturer Specs
17:19 - Sotabeams Bandhopper II Setup and Considerations
18:59 - Making some QSO's on the Bandhopper
21:58 - How to change Bands on the Bandhopper
22:10 - 20m Testing
24:38 - Bandhopper vs Aerial 51 Reflection
26:14 - Packtenna EFHW Setup and Considerations
28:06 - Making some QSO's on the Packtenna on 40m
29:15 - 20m Testing
31:16 - Packtenna (and general EFHW) Observations
33:35 - Conclusion and Final Thoughts on the 3 Wire Antennas

Gear used:
Yaesu FTdx10
RigExpert AA-650 Zoom Analyzer
iPad Pro with Ham2k Polo
PackTenna EFHW
SotaBeams Bandhopper II
Aerial 51 Anentnna: https://www.vibroplex.com/contents/en-us/p3582.html
Spiderbeam Mast: https://www.vibroplex.com/contents/en-us/p3531.html

3D Printed Parts, for Reference:
Thingiverse Spiderbeam 12m Mast Block: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4881368

snippet.title: POTA Road Trip: Arizona to Malibu - 3 Parks, 2 Days
snippet.description:
Join Rory (W8KNX) on a Parks On The Air adventure across the Southwest! This video documents the first time flying with HF ham radio equipment and activating three beautiful parks over two days – from the desert landscapes of Lake Mead to the stunning California coastline at Malibu.

Parks Activated:
US-0676 Lake Mead National Recreation Area (Temple Bar Marina, AZ) - 11/5/2025
US-1204 Topanga State Park (Topanga, CA) - 11/6/2025
US-3537 Point Dume State Beach (Malibu, CA) - 11/6/2025

Equipment Setup:
Radio: Yaesu FT-891 transceiver
Tuner: MAT-TUNER MAT-30
Antenna: PackTenna Mini Random Wire Antenna (9:1 UNUN)
Mast: DX Engineering Nomad 19
Power: 6ah EVOPOW LiFePO4 battery (airline compliant)
Logging: iPad Pro with Ham2K PoLo app
FT8 Audio Interface: Digirig DR-891
FT8 Software: iFTx for iPad 

Watch as Rory navigates the challenges of portable operations with limited battery power, shares tips for flying with radio gear, and makes contacts from incredible locations including a first-ever Japan contact on sideband from Point Dume State Beach in Malibu!

Timestamps:
0:00 - Topanga State Park Setup & Flying with Ham Radio Gear
5:03 - Point Dume State Beach Activation in Malibu
5:47 - First Japan Contact on Sideband!

snippet.title: Can You Put Up An Antenna? The HOA Bill Fight & IC-7300 Mark II
snippet.description:
Send us a text (https://www.buzzsprout.com/twilio/text_messages/2438895/open_sms) 


A thousand subscribers may be a milestone, but the real win is what it represents: a growing community of hams trading ideas, trying new modes, and pushing for the right to put real antennas on real roofs. We open with momentum—POTA activations, contest firsts, and new video drops—then move straight into the issue shaping the future of the hobby: ARRL’s grassroots effort to pass the Amateur Radio Emergency Preparedness Act (HR 1094/S.459). If HOAs block antennas where most new homes are built, fewer operators will get on the air. We explain the stakes, the opposition from CAI, and the surprisingly easy way to send a letter that reaches your representatives in minutes.

We also get practical about life in the shack and on the road. Running 500 to 1,000 watts through contest weekend revealed where filters shine and where they need tuning, and winter prep is now or never—check matches, weatherproof connectors, and tighten your grounding. On the mobile side, an EV install in a Mach‑E delivered clean VHF/UHF performance with smart power routing and a 3D‑printed head mount, plus notes on AM noise under acceleration. If you’ve avoided EVs for RF reasons, this is a reality check rooted in measurements, not myths.

Gear watchers get plenty to chew on. The Icom IC‑7300 Mark II looks set to land around $1,499, squaring up against the Yaesu FTdx10 with modernized I/O and familiar ease of use. But the U.S. government shutdown is delaying FCC certifications across categories, which could push new radio launches past the holidays. Meanwhile, used IC‑7300 prices are compelling, making it a standout first HF rig. We wrap with FlexRadio’s SmartSDR 4.0—meaningful noise‑reduction improvements, a flexible subscription model, and a few early‑release quirks to monitor.

If you care about the bands staying lively and accessible, this conversation matters. Tune in, tell us if you’re backing the ARRL letter, weigh in on 7300 Mark II vs FTdx10, and share your winter station game plan. Subscribe, leave a review on Apple Podcasts or Spotify, and pass this along to a friend who’s antenna‑curious.

Why I love this combo: airline-friendly, no battery anxiety, and the modular bag setup lets me swap between portable and mobile operations. snippet.title: What's in My POTA Bag? Complete Setup for Parks on the Air
snippet.description:
After a full summer season of POTA activations, winter is coming and it's time to clean out the bag! Join James (K8JKU) for a complete walkthrough of his Parks on the Air kit—everything that's been tested in the field and proven reliable throughout the season.

In this detailed tour, you'll discover the exact radios, antennas, power solutions, and accessories that make up a successful POTA kit. Whether you're just getting started with Parks on the Air or looking to upgrade your portable ham radio station, this video covers beginner-friendly options and practical improvements you can make to your own setup.

🎒 COMPLETE POTA BAG CONTENTS - ITEM LIST WITH LINKS:

📻 RADIOS:
• Wouxun KG-Q10H - https://www.buytwowayradios.com/wouxun-kg-q10h.html
• Yaesu FT-891 - https://www.gigaparts.com/yaesu-ft-891-hf-6m-transceiver.html

🔋 POWER:
• Bioenno Power 12V 6Ah LiFePO4 Battery (BLF-1206A) - https://www.bioennopower.com/products/12v-6ah-lifepo4-battery-pvc

💻 DIGITAL INTERFACE:
• Digirig DR-891 (FT-891 Model) - https://digirig.net/product/digirig-dr-891/

📡 ANTENNAS & COMPONENTS:
• Chameleon Antenna M-Coil (black coil) - https://chameleonantenna.com/products/cha-m-coil
• Chameleon Antenna 17 foot whip (SS17) - https://chameleonantenna.com/products/stainless-steal-whip
• Chameleon Antenna spike - https://chameleonantenna.com/products/cha-bv-basic-vertical
• Chameleon 33 ft orange ground radials - https://chameleonantenna.com/
• Packtenna End Fed Half Wave with 40m extension - https://www.packtenna.com/store/p33/EFHW-20/10_-_End_Fed_Half_Wave_20m_and_10m_Antenna.html
• Packtenna 40m Add-On wire - https://www.packtenna.com/store/p32/40m_Add-On_wire_for_20m/10m_EFHW_Antenna.html

🎯 MAST & SUPPORT:
• Gigaparts Explorer ZXP-POTA20 (20ft carbon fiber mast) - https://www.gigaparts.com/explorer-pota20-portable-handheld-20-ft-telescopic-carbon-fiber-mast.html
• PP Man Spike-SH for ZXP-POTA20 Mast - https://980a11.myshopify.com/products/pp-man-spike-sh

🔌 CABLES & ACCESSORIES:
• ABR 174 Coaxial cable - https://abrind.com/product/amateur-radio-coax-builder/

🔧 TEST EQUIPMENT:
• RigExpert Stick Pro - https://www.gigaparts.com/rigexpert-stick-pro-antenna-analyzer.html

📖 REFERENCE & LOGGING:
• Nifty Accessories Band Plan - https://www.gigaparts.com/nifty-accessories-mm-bandplan.html
• Rite in the Rain notebook - https://www.riteintherain.com/

🎒 BACKPACK:
• Gigaparts Explorer Modular Backpack MBP-20 (current model) - https://www.gigaparts.com/explorer-mbp-20-modular-backpack-system-2-0-starter-pack.html

🚗 ADDITIONAL MOBILE SETUP (not in bag):
• Yaesu FT-891 - https://www.gigaparts.com/yaesu-ft-891-hf-6m-transceiver.html
• Yaesu ATAS-120A antenna - https://www.yaesu.com/

💡 Perfect for:
✓ New POTA activators building their first kit
✓ Portable operators looking for gear ideas
✓ Beginner antenna recommendations

📢 Let us know in the comments what's in YOUR POTA bag! How can we improve this setup?

• Packtenna End Fed Half Wave with 40m extension - https://www.packtenna.com/store/p33/EFHW-20/10_-_End_Fed_Half_Wave_20m_and_10m_Antenna.html
• Packtenna 40m Add-On wire - https://www.packtenna.com/store/p32/40m_Add-On_wire_for_20m/10m_EFHW_Antenna.html

🎯 MAST & SUPPORT:
• Gigaparts Explorer ZXP-POTA20 (20ft carbon fiber mast) - https://www.gigaparts.com/explorer-pota20-portable-handheld-20-ft-telescopic-carbon-fiber-mast.html
• PP Man Spike-SH for ZXP-POTA20 Mast - https://980a11.myshopify.com/products/pp-man-spike-sh

🔌 CABLES & ACCESSORIES:
• ABR 174 Coaxial cable - https://abrind.com/product/amateur-radio-coax-builder/

🔧 TEST EQUIPMENT:
• RigExpert Stick Pro - https://www.gigaparts.com/rigexpert-stick-pro-antenna-analyzer.html

📖 REFERENCE & LOGGING:
• Nifty Accessories Band Plan - https://www.gigaparts.com/nifty-accessories-mm-bandplan.html
• Rite in the Rain notebook - https://www.riteintherain.com/

🎒 BACKPACK:
• Gigaparts Explorer Modular Backpack MBP-20 (current model) - https://www.gigaparts.com/explorer-mbp-20-modular-backpack-system-2-0-starter-pack.html

🚗 ADDITIONAL MOBILE SETUP (not in bag):
• Yaesu FT-891 - https://www.gigaparts.com/yaesu-ft-891-hf-6m-transceiver.html
• Yaesu ATAS-120A antenna - https://www.yaesu.com/

✓ New POTA activators building their first kit

snippet.title: New Mustang Mach-E gets Electrified with the Yaesu FTM-500DR Mobile Rig
snippet.description:
Join N8JRD as he cracks open the Mustang Mach-E Electric Vehicle to add a much needed mobile rig.   We take you end to end with the Mach-E, which is actually one of the more straight forward mobile installations that Jim has worked on.  Although we encounter a few challenges, the finished product looks and works great.   

Timestamps:
00:00 - Intro
00:23 - How to get through the Firewall
02:13 - 12v Main Installed
02:43 - Power Relay Installation
04:35 - Connecting to the Radio
05:32  - Secure the Radio Body
06:16 - Connecting to the 12v Battery (Mission Impossible?)
09:08 - Installing the Antenna Cable and Lip Mount
10:55 - Installing the Diamond NR770 Antenna
11:29 - Mounting the Control Head (3d Printed!)
12:10  - Wrap up and Final Install

Parts Used:
Comet RS-520 Lip Mount
Diamond NR770B Antenna
Diamond SO239 Mobile antenna cable (13.5ft coax)
Yaesu FTM-500DR
Bosch Relay
